metadata.case_name: State of Bombay v. R.M.D.C. Mysore Limited

facts.text: In July 1946, first petitioner obtained Licence No. 84 of 1946 from Collector of Bombay under Bombay Prize Competitions Tax Act, 1939, for Littlewoods Football Pool Competitions ending March 31, 1947.
Licence renewed for April 1, 1947 to March 31, 1948; paid Rs. 1 lakh per annum as competition tax to Bombay Provincial Government.
Government of Bombay declined renewal; first petitioner filed petition under s.45 Specific Relief Act, dismissed by Court of Appeal on March 28, 1949.
In August 1948, first petitioner shifted activities to Mysore; promoted and incorporated R.M.D.C. Mysore Limited on February 26, 1949; became Managing Director.
Second petitioner owns weekly newspaper Sporting Star, printed/published at Bangalore; conducts R.M.D.C. Crosswords prize competition; entries received from India including Bombay via agents/depots.
1939 Act and original 1948 Act did not apply to prize competitions in newspapers printed/published outside Bombay.
Mysore Lotteries and Prize Competition Control and Tax Act, 1951 came into force February 1, 1952; second petitioner obtained licence, paid fees and tax at 15% (later 12%) of gross receipts.
Net profit after prizes (33%), taxes (15%), expenses (47%) is about 5%.

Bombay Lotteries and Prize Competitions Control and Tax (Amendment) Act, Bom. XXX of 1952 passed November 20, 1952; deleted exclusion for out-of-state newspapers; inserted cl.(dd) promoter; substituted s.12, inserted s.12A for tax on out-of-state competitions.
Bombay Lotteries and Prize Competitions Control and Tax Rules, 1952 came into force December 8, 1952; require licence in Form H with onerous conditions.
Petitioners filed petition under Art.226 on December 18, 1952, supported by affidavit; challenged impugned Act/Rules as ultra vires for out-of-state publications.
State filed affidavit denying fundamental rights violation, claiming lotteries/competitions opposed to public policy, no business involved.
Single Judge (April 22, 1954) allowed petition, held tax under Entry 60 not 62, exceeds Art.276(2), restrictions violate Art.301/19(1)(g); company citizen entitled to Art.19.
Appeal dismissed by Division Bench January 12, 1955; held competent under Entry 34, but tax under Entry 60 exceeds Art.276(2); restrictions not saved by Art.304(b).
Certificate under Arts.132(1),133(1) granted; appeal to SC.

legal_issues.text: Whether impugned Act (1948 Act as amended by Bom. XXX/1952) and Rules valid: legislative competence under Entries 33,34,62 State List; or under 26,60; tax exceeds Art.276(2); extra-territorial operation.
Whether prize competitions are gambling/lotteries or legitimate trade/business protected by Art.19(1)(g)/301.
Whether sufficient territorial nexus for taxing out-of-state newspaper competitions.
Whether restrictions reasonable in public interest under Art.19(6)/304(b).

petitioner_arguments.text: Impugned Act beyond competence: not betting/gambling (Entry 34), entertainments (33), taxes thereon (62); but trade/commerce (26), tax on trade (60); exceeds Art.276(2) limit Rs.250.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Entries 26,60 State List; Art.276(2); s.142A GOI Act 1935

petitioner_arguments.text: Prize competition not lottery/gambling: requires skill, knowledge, judgment; Act distinguishes competitions/lotteries.
Violates Art.301, not saved by 304(b); unreasonable restrictions not in public interest; violates Art.19(1)(g)/14.
Company is citizen entitled to Art.19.

respondent_arguments.text: Prize competitions are lotteries/gambling opposed to public policy; no trade/business; Act under Entries 33,34,62.
No violation Art.19(1)(g) as no business; corporation not citizen.
Restrictions reasonable in public interest; no violation Art.301/304(b).
No extra-territoriality; ss.10,12 not violate Art.14.

court_reasoning.text: Act valid under Entry 34 (betting/gambling); definition s.2(1)(d) covers only gambling prize competitions; first category qualified by 'solution prepared beforehand or by lot/chance'; read 'or' as 'and'; no innocent competitions included.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prize competitions in Act are gambling nature, allied to lotteries; s.3 declares both unlawful subject to Act.

court_reasoning.text: s.12A tax is on betting/gambling (Entry 62), not trade (60); percentage on entry fees from Bombay, collected from promoters conveniently; indirect tax on gamblers.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tax on gross receipts from Bombay entries, not profits; Legislature intended under Entry 62 to avoid Art.276(2) limit.

court_reasoning.text: Sufficient territorial nexus: newspaper circulated in Bombay, depots/collectors appointed, entries/fees paid in Bombay; tax only on Bombay receipts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Activities (invitation, filling forms, payment) occur in Bombay.

court_reasoning.text: Promotion of gambling prize competitions not 'trade/business' under Art.19(1)(g)/301; opposed to public policy; State may regulate/suppress.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Gambling not commerce; Australian cases (Connare, Martin) support suppression not burden on inter-state trade.

court_reasoning.text: Even if applicable, restrictions reasonable in public interest under Art.19(6)/304(b); President's assent cures procedural defect.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Art.255 cures lack of prior Presidential sanction.

holdings.text: Impugned Act valid legislation on betting/gambling (Entry 34); tax under s.12A valid under Entry 62; no extra-territoriality.
Prize competitions under Act are gambling, not protected trade/business under Art.19(1)(g)/301.
No violation of Arts.19/301; restrictions saved.

precedents_cited.relevance: Prize competition where solution prepared beforehand is gambling: blind shots at hidden target.
Football pool under English s.26(a); not directly on skill.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hindu Women's Rights to Property Act case
precedents_cited.relevance: Principle to cut down scope if literal makes invalid.
Tax on promoter passed to gamblers.
Lotteries suppression not violate s.92 Australian Constitution; gambling not trade.
Similar; law penalises aleatory acts, not trade.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commonwealth of Australia v. Bank of New South Wales
precedents_cited.relevance: Banking is trade; s.92 protects legitimate business.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court holds impugned Act and s.12A valid under Entries 34/62; sufficient nexus; gambling not protected trade under Art.19(1)(g)/301; reverses High Court judgments allowing writ petition.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal allowed; High Court orders set aside; State permitted to enforce Act/Rules.

key_quotes.text: "a competition in order to avoid the stigma of gambling must depend to a substantial degree upon the exercise of skill."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the tax sought to be imposed by the impugned Act is a percentage of the aggregate of the entry fees received from the State of Bombay. On ultimate analysis it is a tax on each entry fee received from each individual competitor."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "gambling is not trade, commerce or intercourse within the meaning alike of s.92 of the Australian Constitution and our Art.19(1)(g) and Art.301."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding excluding gambling from constitutional protection.

key_quotes.text: "the standing invitations, the filling up of the forms and the payment of money take place within the State which is seeking to tax only the amount received by the petitioners from the State of Bombay."
key_quotes.speaker: court
